data.name: Tab_Start_Intro.Text
data.value: This wizard will guide you in the creation of your very own physical simulation. We will define the rules, properties, and parameters that govern how your universe works. You will have the choice of either specifying these variables yourself, or allowing us to randomize them for you.

data.name: Tab_Start_Quote.Text
data.value: An intellect which at a certain moment would know all forces that set nature in motion, and all positions of all items of which nature is composed, if this intellect were also vast enough to submit these data to analysis, it would embrace in a single formula the movements of the greatest bodies of the universe and those of the tiniest atom; for such an intellect nothing would be uncertain and the future just like the past would be present before its eyes. --Pierre-Simon Laplace

data.name: Tab_ParticleSeed_Desc.Text
data.value: Here we will specify how particles and other objects will be seeded with starting values and positions when we start the simulation. You have the choice of either manually setting up this configuration, or letting a script do it for you.

data.name: Tab_Interactions_Tabs_Update_Desc.Text
data.value: Update scripts lay out the core algorithm for how each generation, or step of time, is processed by the simulation. These scripts utilize the interaction scripts to calculate the overall changes in say, the acceleration or velocity, on a particle due to forces on that particle caused by every other particle in the simulation. You may only have one update script to control the simulation.

data.name: Tab_Interactions_Tabs_Interactions_Desc.Text
data.value: Interaction scripts represent some kind of interaction between objects (Particles, Fields, Waves, etc.) within the simulation and are usually forces such as gravity or friction. You may select as many interaction scripts as you would like.

data.name: Tab_Interactions_Desc.Text
data.value: Now that we have defined the size and behavior of space as a whole, it's time to determine what kinds of natural laws will govern the interactions between objects in our universe. Simplex Universe uses update scripts and interaction scripts to define these laws.

data.name: Tab_Parameters_Desc.Text
data.value: Next we need to set up global simulation parameters. These are usually numerical values that represent physical constants used by interaction scripts or values that limit or modify calculations done by the update script. Example simulation parameters include "GravitationalConstant", "MaximumVelocity", and "Precision". To make a value infinite, type "Infinity" as its value.

data.name: Tab_Properties_Desc.Text
data.value: Now we will define the different possible properties available to particles in our simulation such as "Mass" or "Charge". The accepted value range for these properties will be specified using the standard mathematical notation for value ranges. The property "Mass" has been automatically added as an example. If you wish, we can also import all of the neccessary properties based on your interaction scripts.

data.name: Tab_Dimensions_Description.Text
data.value: The first thing we want to determine is the number of dimensions that our universe contains. This is the minimum number of points neccessary to describe the position of an object within our space. Most simulations will take place in either 2D or 3D space, but you may choose any number that you wish.

data.name: Tab_UniverseProperties_Tabs_Size_Desc.Text
data.value: Select the radius (in units) that you want your universe to have and when you are finished, select a boundary type in the "Boundary" tab. If you would like an infinite universe, drag the track bar all the way to the right. Infinite universes don't need boundary scripts.
